name: Belt of Thomas (Sacra Cintola)
shortDescription: The miraculous belt allegedly given by the Virgin Mary to Thomas at her Assumption - a legendary relic connecting Thomas's doubt to Marian devotion
fullDescription: The Belt of Thomas (also called the Girdle of Thomas, Sacra Cintola, or Holy Belt) is a legendary relic with roots in medieval tradition connecting the apostle Thomas to the Assumption of the Virgin Mary. According to the legend, which developed in the medieval period and became especially popular in Italy, Thomas was absent when Mary died and was assumed into heaven (mirroring his absence at Christ's resurrection appearance). When Thomas arrived, he initially doubted the other apostles' account of Mary's assumption - consistent with his character as the 'doubter.' As confirmation, Mary dropped her girdle (belt or sash) down to Thomas from heaven, providing the physical proof he characteristically required. This legend serves multiple theological functions: it rehabilitates Thomas by making his doubt serve a positive purpose (providing tangible evidence of the Assumption), it reinforces the doctrine of Mary's bodily assumption, and it connects the apostolic witness to Marian devotion. The most famous claimed relic is the Sacra Cintola (Holy Belt) venerated at the Cathedral of Prato in Tuscany, Italy, which has been housed there since approximately the 12th century. The relic is displayed five times a year from an external pulpit designed by Donatello and Michelozzo. Other churches have also claimed to possess portions of this belt. While the legend has no basis in canonical scripture or early tradition (the Assumption itself is not in the Bible but developed as church tradition), the Belt of Thomas became an important devotional object and artistic motif, particularly in Renaissance Italian art where the scene of Mary giving her belt to Thomas became a common subject.

legend.narrative: When the Virgin Mary died and was assumed bodily into heaven, Thomas was absent (just as he was absent at Christ's first resurrection appearance). When he arrived and heard what had happened, he characteristically doubted. As proof, Mary dropped her belt down from heaven to Thomas, providing tangible evidence of her assumption.
legend.firstAppearance: The legend appears to have developed in the early medieval period, possibly 8th-9th century, though the Prato relic claims origins in the 1st century
legend.function: The legend serves to: (1) Provide apostolic testimony to the Assumption, (2) Rehabilitate Thomas by making his doubt constructive, (3) Create a physical connection between earth and heaven, (4) Parallel Thomas's demand for proof of Christ's resurrection

pratoRelic.location: Cathedral of Santo Stefano, Prato, Tuscany, Italy
pratoRelic.history: According to local tradition, a merchant named Michele brought the relic from the Holy Land in 1141 after marrying a woman whose family possessed it. It was donated to the Cathedral of Prato in 1174.
pratoRelic.displayPulpit: The relic is displayed from an external pulpit (Pulpito del Sacro Cingolo) with reliefs by Donatello and architectural design by Michelozzo (1428-1438)
pratoRelic.materialDescription: The relic is described as a green woolen or silk girdle approximately 87 cm long with golden threads

artHistory.popularSubject: The 'Madonna della Cintola' (Madonna of the Girdle) became a popular subject in Italian Renaissance art

artHistory.iconography: Typically shows Mary in heavenly glory, surrounded by angels, dropping or handing her belt down to Thomas who stands below with upraised hands

theologicalConnections.thomasParallel: Just as Thomas doubted the resurrection until given proof (John 20:24-29), he doubted the Assumption until given proof. His doubt again serves to provide evidence for those who were not present.
theologicalConnections.assumptionDoctrine: The legend supports belief in Mary's bodily assumption, later defined as dogma by Pope Pius XII in 1950 (Munificentissimus Deus)
theologicalConnections.relicTheology: The belt represents physical connection between heaven and earth, tangible proof of the supernatural
